title: Image Processing Project
text:
Image processing usually convert images to grayscale, resize them, and create visualizations. The mathematical foundation uses matrix operations where each pixel has a value \(p_{i,j}\).




We can use simple image transformations: - Load images - Convert to grayscale

Then we can create outputs: - Save processed images - Generate surface plots - Create gradient maps




Usually the process includes:

Load: Read image files from data folder
Transform: Apply grayscale and resize
Rotate: Rotate image by -90 degrees
Analyze: Compute gradients
Save: Export all results





The basic image transformation formula is:
\[
I'(x,y) = T(I(x,y))
\]
where \(I'\) is the transformed image and \(T\) is our transformation function.


graph LR
    A[Input] --> B[Grayscale]
    B --> C[Resize]
    C --> D[Rotate]
    D --> E[Save]





Image processing helps us understand visual data.

Results should show good performance as the follow example:



Step
Time (ms)
Quality

title: Image Processing Project
text:
Processing Pipeline
Image processing workflow includes several key steps:

Input: Load images from data directory
Transform: Apply grayscale conversion and geometric transformations

Analyze: Generate gradient maps and surface plots
Output: Save processed images and generate reports

Technical Approach
The methodology draws from recent advances in computer vision (Vaswani et al. 2017) and classical image processing techniques (Chua 1997).

Chua, Leon O. 1997. “CNN: A Vision of Complexity.” International Journal of Bifurcation and Chaos 7 (10): 2219–2425.


Vaswani, Ashish, Noam Shazeer, Niki Parmar, Jakob Uszkoreit, Llion Jones, Aidan N Gomez, Łukasz Kaiser, and Illia Polosukhin. 2017. “Attention Is All You Need.” Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 30.
